name: Javier Bonnemaison
text: Bryan Guffey Whatever business model Atlassian decided to deploy, it was based on their needs and strategy. They are not doing free users any favors, they simply assume that some of them will convert to paid and perhaps generate some positive reviews and/or referral sales, and they are calculating that this is a good investment. Offering this service in good faith includes taking reasonable measures to protect and preserve user content, as well as making it easy for people to take their content with them for any reason (I assume that Atlassian does not provide a tool to conveniently do this, as it would harm user lock-in, but I may be wrong). Ultimately, they are free to change their commercial terms, but they still have a responsibility to protect user content to the best of their abilities. Regulation could, for example, require companies to archive user accounts for a full year after termination in a portable format (like markdown) and contact users repeatedly via multiple channels if possible. In the current world, if a manager decides that they want to cut storage costs or make some other KPI look better this quarter, and that involves deleting user accounts after minimal warning, users have no recourse whatsoever.

text:
Atlassian begins sending emails 60 days prior to product deactivation due to inactivity.

They send emails on day 60, day 30, day 7, and day 0. On day 0, they inform you that your product has been deactivated. At the time of deactivation, the site admin still has *another* 60 days to reactivate their account.

This means your friend managed to ignore her life's work for two months (totally understandable, life happens), miss the emails, and then go *another* two months without trying to reactivate.

If you friend ran out of space, she would've only been restricted to what she could do in Confluence and as long as she either upgraded to a paid plan (only $6.70/month, paid monthly) or just kept logging back in every 59 days, her data would never have been deleted nor her account deactivated. Additionally, Atlassian provides built-in backup tools for users to use that are point and click.

I am finding it difficult to have much anger at Atlassian in this situation. I feel for your friend, but if this was much of her life's work, it also feels like a significant lack of personal responsibility for this data.

Oh my, that‚Äôs an extremely brutal frustrating lesson for sure. My heart goes out to your friend.

I don‚Äôt think that Atlassian is to blame here, though.

There are three fundamental rules for safeguarding business continuity:
1. Make backups from day one
2. Make backups elsewhere from day one
3. Automate all your backups from day one

Exactly _because_ life happens and you might not be capable of doing what‚Äôs necessary when something unexpected happens.

It‚Äôs mindblowing how many people still naively rely on a single storage for their most valuable data. Both professionally and in their private life. Help them become aware, please.
